Hey Jim,  

I will try to respond more thoroughly now that I've su=
bmitted my

ready 
worked through these issues.  But as I said before, my 
implementati=
on of NEAT does not run inputs through any kind of 
activation function, so=
 in fact I agree with you on everything here.

On the other hand, running i=
nputs through an activation can be seen 
as just one of many possible ways =
of scaling or normalizing inputs 
to get them in the best form for an ANN. =
 In that sense, maybe in 
some cases there is a good intuition behind doing=
 it, but on the 
face of it, it does seem ad hoc to me, i.e. why use a sigm=
oid of all 
possible methods for normalization?  

Still, normalization in =
the broader sense is a good idea. (This sort 
of answers part C of your que=
stion.)  So in other words, if there is 
an input that naturtally varies fr=
om 0 to 1,000,000, you proabably 
want to compress that range a lot sending=
 it into the net.  So 
the "activation function" would be the function that=
 compresses the 
range.  But that really shouldn't be called an "activation=
 
function," since it's really just data preprocessing, and also 
because d=
ifferent inputs in the same net probably should be 
normalized in different=
 ways.
